title: How historically accurate is the 'Death of Stalin' movie? - Quora

response.answer_text: The film is so historically inaccurate that it serves more to slander some real people, some of which were or are still considered national or even international heroes. Some Examples. In the movie Marshall Zhukov, incorrectly referred to as field marshal Zhukov, plays a central role he didn’t have. Zhukov was appointed minister after Stalin’s death. He was a commander in the far east before that. He helped to arrest Beria 3 months after Stalin’s death, not immediately after. Beria by the way, was not in charge of the secret police, or the NKVD. Particularly not the NKVD, which was disbanded in 1946. He was the minister of internal affairs during Stalin’s death. Unlike in the movie Molotov was not the foreign minister, he was fired from that post in 1949, and only became so again after Stalin’s death, as far as I know he played no part in the events around Stalin’s death, though he does in the movie. The whole central cast was not even gathered for the events, which obviously were not nearly as ridiculous, as they are made out to be. Also, the whole tone of the movie, sadly isn’t about Stalin, nor about his supporters being bad. It’s about all of Soviets, all of Russians being wholesomely bad and funny only because of how incompetent and casually evil they all are. It implies Russians are still like this, and serves have some propaganda value in this. Kruschev and the Anti-Stalinist faction is also not portrayed as any better, they try to portray Kruschev as very sleazy. When in reality, he was the one who tried to reorganize the government to not be so dictatorial, and later denounced Stalinism entirely. In short, the movie is historically inaccurate to the point of a fairytale, and beyond comedy highly biased in it’s presentation of history.

Let’s see the historical facts.  The Nineteenth Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union was held from 5 to 14 October 1952 - 19th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union - Wikipedia. Below Stalin and Malenkov.  On 16 October the Central Committee kept a plenary meeting. After 70 years, Stalin’s 1-hour and 30-minute speech is still secret. However, it is known that Stalin labelled Molotov and Vorosilov British spies - the wives of the 2 politicians being meanwhile imprisoned. During the elections, Stalin rejected the following: Andreev, Vorosilov, Kaganovich, Kosigin, Mikoyan and Molotov. Even more strange was the fact the Central Committee ignored Stalin’s veto and chose all of them. Below Voroshilov, Beria and Malenkov  The politburo had 11 members: Stalin, Malenkov, Beria, Bulganin, Vorosilov, Kaganovich, Kosygin, Mikoyan, Molotov, Khrushchev and Andreev + 1 substitute member Shvernik. In order to manage ‘’the rebellion’’, Stalin proposed to increase the Central Committee number from 12 to 36. The proposal was accepted but the newcomers weren’t used with the high level political tricks while the old guard kept united as they feared they would be purged. Stalin understood he couldn’t rely on the newcomers and he ordered the arrests of all doctors of the ‘’rebellious’’ CC members. Starting with 5th of January, most of the friends or family of Khrushchev, Malenkov, Voroshilov or Kaganovich were arrested. Beria’s associates were most heavily hit. Stalin also fired the chief of his personal guards the General Vlasik and his own personal secretary Pokrebisev. Due to his paranoia Stalin was alone. Below Kaganovici, Bulganin and Kruschev  One day before Stalin’s death, Beria, Malenkov, Bulganin and Khrushchev visited Stalin’s villa for reconciliation. After they left, nobody ever saw Stalin conscious. The next day the world was informed that Stalin was ill. Nobody knows exactly what happened.  On 5 March 1953 the CC Plenary of USSR met at 20′40 in a 10 minutes meeting. Stalin was not dead yet. The first decision was Stalin’s removal from his position as Central Committee secretary. The CC number was restored to the previous 11 members, all newcomers were removed. 2 pro-Stalin members, Kosygin and Andreev were replaced by Pervuhin and Saburov. At 21′30 Stalin finally died. Officially Stalin died on 5 of March 1953, however the new chief of the government, Malenkov, was appointed on 4th of March. 😁   In 1953 after a workers’ rebellion in East Berlin, Beria, who coordinated the repression returned to Moscow with the proposal to stop building socialism in East Germany.East German uprising of 1953 - Wikipedia.  On the 25th of June, Beria returned from Berlin being convinced that communism was not possible in East Germany. On the 26th of June, he was arrested as well as his most important associates. The leader of the group who arrested Beria was Zhukov. After this action Zhukov became full member of CC. In December 1953, the trial of Beria was conducted by Marshal Konev. General Baritki shot Beria. On the 13th of September 1953 Khrushchev was appointed prime-secretary of the CC of PCUS . On the 13th of March, 1954 Khrushchev founded KGB, replacing all various secret services coordinated by Beria. The 20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union was held during the period 14–25 February 1956. It is known especially for First Secretary Nikita Khrushchev's "Secret Speech", which denounced the personality cult and dictatorship of Joseph Stalin.

Most of the stuff that the movie refers to happened in one form or another: a concert that was on live radio, and then the orchestra had to create a recording especially for Stalina religious pianist whose family was killed and who sent Stalin a note saying that she prays for his soulStalin had a private cinema and loved cowboy filmsMolotov’s wife was in Gulag, and he denounced herStalin’s daughter was in love with Alexei, who was sent to GulagAll the best doctors were dead/in jail at the time of Stalin’s deathArmy hated NKVDStalin’s son had a pet ice hockey team, and there was a plane crashDeath lists that everyone in the politburo had to signKhrushchev was known as the class clown, and probably survived by playing the “dumb, funny, and harmless” role.Obviously the movie’s (and the original book’s) authors modified some events, and brought them closer in time for dramatic impact. And of course played them as farce, because this is the genre of that movie, not realistic history drama.

No. Many details are inaccurate, and of course, the movie is intended to be a dark comedy, not even a historical drama. They took significant liberties just to make the material more comedy-friendly. About the only part that is pretty much as described in the history books is Stalin’s actual death, with the uncertainties inherent in that there were few people present, and none of them had any particular reason to make sure any description was accurate. But there is one thing I think they got spot on. The absurdity. The feeling of everything being a shambles, and unlikely to get sorted even if they sat down and tried, which they were too busy backstabbing each other to do. The underlying dynamics, that they all had so powerful holds on each other that their room for manoeuvring was severely restricted. The pettiness and vindictiveness. The feeling that despite being the undisputed, absolute leaders of the country, they were in actual fact powerless to change or even control the situation.

Yes. In that there really was a man called Josef Stalin, who really was the dictator of the Soviet Union, and who really died, that’s completely true. His death occurred in roughly the way that the film (I’ve not read the graphic novel I understand the film is based on) portrays - specifically that he lingered for a while, and this led to a rather complicated power struggle between his various lieutenants, which played out in roughly the way that the film shows. Some of the actors also look uncannily like the people they were portraying. Michael Palin and Vyacheslav Molotov could be distant relatives, based on some photos of the latter. The actual dialogue is largely invented for comic effect, of course.

Fairly accurate if you take out the humor. Including Stalin lying in his own piss, Beria and the gang deciding not to call doctors, delaying the announcement of his death and driving over to Kremlin to burn any documents that might contain information who should be the next leader of the USSR. Whether it was Beria or if it was Khrushchev who plotted the scheme will always be a mystery although most people think it was the former who was the ringleader. Zhores Medvedev writes an extremely accurate account of the events leading up to the death and thereafter. For those more inclined towards suspense Archangel is a good movie.

Amazingly so, but not so much so that you can take it as history. It takes events that are known to have happened and adds gags. Someone I saw the move with described it as a documentary interspersed with slapstick. In truth, Stalin had at least 600,000 Soviet officials murdered in his purges, which went on most of his premiership. This is in addition to the millions of deaths through his intentional famine and collectivization of agriculture. Having people shot was his favorite method of purging. His daughter Svetlana Stalin’s mother did commit suicide. She did it at least in part to protest Stalin’s Ukrainian famine. His son was a general and died a young age of alcoholism. Some historians say there is reason to believe that security chief Beria did prevent medical attention for Stalin for quite some time after the stroke, although it cannot be proved or disproved. Beria used his power to force young girls and women to have sex with him. and when rumors that Stalin had been struck ill there was a race among at least some Stalin lieutenants to get to his dacha first.

The "Death of Stalin" movie is historical (maybe hysterical) fiction. My favorite movie is Amadeus. It also is not historically accurate instead it uses the historical facts and character as a structure. The characters in the movies are not related to the real people. For example, historically Salieri was not such a villain and was not the person who took down dictation of Mozart’s Requiem. The movie was not really about Mozart and Salieri but was an exploration of human envy. I consider "Death of Stalin" the same way. They are both fictionalized versions of history. BTW, if Donald Trump loses the election I am waiting for the producer to make a movie of the aftermath.

It is a caricature, a comic exaggeration. Nothing more - but it is an exaggeration of facts. I will never understand how the toadies around Stalin thought their positions were valuable enough to put up with the humiliation and the very high risk of torture and death. Molotov having his wife apparently sentenced to death in the gulag and continuing to serve… how was that possible? A hint of the quality of the toadies can be gained when Stalin screwed up his diplomacy and his management of the Red Army so badly that Hitler was able to waltz into the USSR. He apparently retreated to his dacha and waited for some-one to come and either shoot him or put him on public trial. Instead the top of the politburo flapped around for a while, and then came to his door to beg him to save them. Unbelievably disgusting.
Was “The Life of Bryan” an accurate depiction of the events leading to the birth of Christianity? Both are comedies. They shoot comedies to make people laugh.

“the Death of Stalin” is a bad movie. There is no single trustworthy character in it. They all are ridiculously non-Russian and non-Soviet. But the main theme is correct - there was strugle for power between Beria, Malenkov, Khruschov and Zhukov after Stalin’s death.
While some elements of the movie are factual, it is also a dark comedy, and history is exaggerated to make the situations funny. I wouldn’t be using that movie in a research paper anytime soon.
